_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: API 570 Piping Inspection of Flare Circuit 8"-PVT-7401
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Expandable Polystyrene (EPS) is manufactured in a 1-step batch process by free-radical initiated suspension polymerization of styrene.  Water is the suspension media used in the reaction.  It is pumped into any one of five (5) batch reactors (E-R-14, E-R-15, E-R-16, E-R-17, E-R-18) located in Building 4.  Liquid styrene is then pumped from on-site tank farm storage to the reactor. Free radical initiators, suspending agents, and other additives are added to the reactor. Reactor contents are heated to initiate the polymerization then cooled to control the temperature of the exothermic reaction once it has begun for the duration of the polymerization.  Asthe styrene polymerizes it forms small polystyrene beads approximately 1,000 microns in diameter.  During the styrene addition to the reactor and the polymerization reaction, the reactor vapors are vented through a condenser to a flare system.  At the conclusion of the polymerization reaction, the reactor is isolated from the flare system and liquid pentane is pumped from on-site tank farm storage into the reactor.  Pentane vaporizes in the reactor, generating pressure that causes pentane to diffuse into the polystyrene beads.  In addition, reactor temperature is increased to improve pentane diffusion and to polymerize trace amounts of remaining styrene.
At the conclusion of pentane diffusion, the reactor is cooled, the water/EPS bead slurry is discharged to the reactor?s given storage tank commonly called a wash tank (E-T-14, E-T-15, E-T-16, E-T-17, E-T-18) and the reactor is prepared for the next batch to be produced.  Reactors are used sequentially as batches are completed to allow as near continuous operation as possible.
The water/EPS bead slurry is pumped from the wash tank to one of four (4) centrifuges (E-K-08, E-K-09, E-K-10, E-K-11) where the EPS beads are separated from the water (dewatered).
The de-watered EPS beads are vacuum conveyed to and dried in one of four (4) drier systems (E-D-07, E-D-09, E-D-10, E-D-11).
Dried EPS beads are pressure conveyed to one of three (3) screening systems (sieves) and screened to segregate them by size.
Screened EPS beads are pressure conveyed to packaging bins (J-BI-A, J-BI-B, J-BI-01, J-BI-02, J-BI-03, J-BI-04, J-BI-05, J-BI-06, J-BI-07, J-BI-08, J-BI-09, J-BI-10) in the packaging area.
Screened EPS beads are mixed with liquid and/or powdered lubricating external additives and packaged for shipment to customers.

EPS can also be manufactured in a 2-step process that varies from the 1-step process in that polystyrene beads previously formed and screened or micropellets (neither containing pentane) are added to a reactor with water.  The mixture is heated, pentane is added, and pentane diffusion takes place as in the 1-step process.   Processing after the reactor is the same as the 1-step process with the exception that no screening is necessary because the polystyrene beads or micropellets added to the reactor at the start of the process were previously screened or produced to the appropriate size.

Each reactor is vented to the flare system through a vent condenser.  Each reactor also has an atmospheric vent that can be used during sampling reactor contents or making manual additions of chemicals to the reactor.  Each reactor has a rupture disk that vents outside the process area and an emergency discharge valve that can be used to empty reactor contents to a containment area.
The wash tanks are normally operated under a slight positive pressure due to a constant nitrogen purge and are vented to the flare system.  Each wash tank is also equipped with a manually activated vent to atmosphere and a manually operated drain valve.

Exhaust from each of the dewatering and drying systems is vented through cyclones to prevent discharge of EPS beads.

Wastewater that is separated from the EPS beads is discharged through a process wastewater sump to the plant?s wastewater treatment system.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Pentane Tank Farm - The Peru facility operates a pentane tank farm
consisting of two 30,000 gallon storage tanks that contain pentane. The relief vents are set at 14.5 psig for the two tanks.  The pentane comes to the facility via truck and rail.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Summary of RMP Elements
All of the information submitted to the USEPA is as of June 16, 2009.

1.Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
Flint Hills Resources, LP - Peru Facility (the ?Peru Facility?) is committed to providing a safe, healthy and environmentally conscious work-place for its employees and neighbors. The Peru Facility maintains a working PSM program, which implements a series of steps designed to prevent potential hazards associated with the process and provide a well-trained work force. The PSM program further implements its policies with onsite procedures and manuals. The Peru Facility coordinates emergency response activities primarily with the City of Peru Fire Department. In addition, in an actual emergency, the City of LaSalle Fire Department, LaSalle County LEPC, and other sources of emergency response may be called on to provide mutual aid. The Peru Facility assists local officials in the development of emergency procedures to identify resources, chemicals, contacts and material safety data sheets for participating companies. Since its certification in November 1993, the Peru Facility has been a participant in the International Standards Organization (ISO) 9002 quality management program.

2.Regulated Substances.
The Peru Facility manufactures polystyrene-based products consisting of one main process area where expandable polystyrene (EPS) is produced and a tank farm where the regulated substance is stored. The polymers are produced in a batch process. The Peru Facility has one RMP-regulated substance, pentane (flammable liquid), at the facility. The pentane is impregnated inside the polystyrene to cause the beads to expand when heated by the end user.

3. General accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps.
Following is a brief summary of the elements that the Peru Facility has implemented to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements outlined by the EPA as well as with t

he Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) standard.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
The Peru Facility maintains a compilation of current written safety information to identify and understand the hazards of the process. This includes information pertaining to:
? Hazards of regulated substances: For each applicable substance, there is a Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) which discusses the physical properties of the chemicals, exposure hazards, the required personal protective equipment and the appropriate first aid and emergency treatment for exposure.
? The technology of the process: Includes a discussion of process chemistry, safe upper and lower limits of temperature and pressure and analysis of consequences of deviation.
? Equipment in the process: Includes such information as materials of construction, diagrams of the piping and instrumentation, safety systems and design codes.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS
The Peru Facility has performed process hazard analysis on each covered process to identify the potential hazards, the adequacy of the engineering and administrative controls and the ways to minimize those hazards. The Peru Facility utilizes the HAZOP methodology, a recognized and generally accepted method, for identifying and evaluating hazards in the process. The Peru Facility assigns employees to the HAZOP team who are knowledgeable in the HAZOP methodology and the specific process. The HAZOP team develops recommendations to reduce the potential hazards which, if approved, are to be implemented within a reasonable period of time.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
The Peru Facility maintains written operating procedures that were developed in consultation with operators, designed to
provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities associated with a covered process. The procedures address steps for all operating phases, safety systems, control measures and precautions to prevent exposures to process hazards. The procedures

are reviewed and revised periodically to maintain their accuracy and completeness.

TRAINING
The Peru Facility provides initial training as well as refresher training to employees so that the required level of skills and knowledge are to be maintained. The training emphasizes safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices. Operators receive periodic refresher training.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
The Peru Facility has developed written procedures for maintaining the operating components of the process (including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown system controls, and pumps) through the mechanical integrity program. The program is comprised of trained personnel who are to follow maintenance, testing and inspection procedures designed to ensure proper function of process equipment.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
The Peru Facility has established and implemented written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and any changes to the facility that affect a covered process. The procedures are designed such that, prior to any change, the following issues are to be considered: the technical basis for the proposed change, its impact on safety and health, any modifications to operating procedures, the necessary time period for the change, and any authorization requirements. Employees involved in operating a process, as well as maintenance and contract employees whose job will be affected, are to be informed of and trained in the change. If necessary, the process safety information and operating procedures are to be updated.

PRE-START UP REVIEW
The Peru Facility performs pre-startup safety reviews when the addition of or a modification to the facility is made that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information. The pre-startup safety review is designed to confirm, prior to the introduction of highly hazardous chemicals, that construc

tion and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; management-of-change requirements are met; and training of employees affected by modifications is complete.

COMPLIANCE AUDIT
The Peru Facility performs audits of its compliance with the provisions of its process safety management program. Teams comprised of employees and/or consultants with appropriate knowledge of audit techniques, process safety and operating experience, conduct audits every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. The findings of the audit team are reviewed and appropriate corrective actions are implemented and tracked until resolved.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
The Peru Facility investigates incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of covered chemicals. The investigation is to be promptly conducted, commencing within 48 hours of any incident. To perform the investigation, the Peru Facility has established an incident investigation team consisting of persons with the appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. A report is prepared at the conclusion of the incident investigation that addresses the incident, thefactors that contributed to it, and recommendations resulting from the incident investigation. The Peru Facility has established a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations and to document their resolution. Finally, incident reports are to be reviewed with all affected personnel.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
The Peru Facility has developed a written action plan for employee participation designed to cover all aspects of its process safety management program. The Peru Facility consults with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of PHAs and on the development of other elements of the process safety

management program. The Peru Facility provides employees with access to PHAs and all other process safety management information.

HOT WORK PERMIT
The Peru Facility employs a hot work permit program for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process (hot work generally involves electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing or similar spark-producing operations). If hot work is to be performed near a covered process, the Peru Facility issues a permit that documents the fire prevention and protection requirements for the operation, the date authorized for hot work, and the object on which the work is performed. Hot work permits are to be kept on file until the work is complete.

CONTRACTORS
The Peru Facility has developed procedures for selecting contractors that are competent and knowledgeable and can safely perform their work. The Peru facility provides information to them about the hazards that may be present in the work area and has developed safe work practices. The Peru Facility also evaluates the safety performance and programs of the contractors as a part of their continued employment.

4. Five Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases of pentane that have resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage at or associated with the Peru facility within the last 5 years.

However, pursuant to EPA?s General Risk Management Program Guidance, Chapter 3, Section 3.1 (March 13, 2009) (the ?Guidance?), described below, FHR has elected to report one incident in the RMP out of an abundance of caution. 

?If you have had a release of a regulated substance from a process where the regulated substance is held below its threshold quantity, you do not need to report that release even if the release caused one of the listed impacts or if the process is covered for some other substance. You may choose to report the release in

the five-year accident history, but you are not required to do so.?

The incident being reported occurred on 9/9/08. The Facility experienced an electrical arc incident as a result of water leaking through a roof, that caused a considerable amount of damage to a motor control center ("MCC room") at the Facility. It is expected that a small amount of NO was released due to the arc event. The process is covered for pentane, but not for NO. In addition, the arc incident caused the loss of the Facility's flare for a period of approximately 77 hours, which resulted in a small amount of pentane being released to the atmosphere from the flare header. However, as discussed above, neither the release of pentane nor NO caused any property damage. Rather, the arc incident caused the damage which led to the release of small amounts of the chemicals noted. The amount of NO released is not known, but is assumed to be less than 1 lb, so the maximum of 1 lb was reported. The amount of pentane released was calculated from production data at 195 lbs.

5. Emergency Response Program.
The Peru Facility has a written emergency response program that contains procedures to be followed in the case of an accidental release of a regulated substance. These procedures include steps for informing the public, proper first aid and medical treatment, the proper use of emergency equipment and emergency response training. The emergency response plan is reviewed annually and updated as necessary. Likewise, the emergency response equipment is maintained, tested, and inspected periodically. The Peru Facility is actively involved with informing local stakeholders about hazardous substances stored and
processed at the facility. The Peru Facility participates with the City of Peru Fire Department, the City of LaSalle Fire Department, the LaSalle County LEPC and others in assisting local officials in the development of emergency procedures to identify resources, chemicals, contacts and material safety data
